Triggering Event: The phone rings, shattering the late-night silence of his empty apartment. It's the station; they need him to come in, now. There's been a shooting at an old crime scene. His heart races as he dresses quickly, fingers fumbling with buttons and belt. The echoes of that long-ago case thunder in his mind, drowning out the quiet hum of the city outside.
Generated Assessment: Fuck this shit! I'll never be able to sleep again. Every time my phone rings in the middle of the night, it's always for something bad. They're probably calling me about another body, another dead kid, another life lost. Why does it always have to be me? I'm the one who gets pulled into these dark scenes over and over. It never ends, just keeps piling up until I can't handle it anymore. Why do they keep picking me? Is there something wrong with me? Am I meant to be the one who has to see all the worst parts of humanity? I feel like I've already seen too much, but then they call me back in, and I'm right back where I started, reliving memories I wish I could forget. This is why I hate my job. I know I signed up to help solve crimes, but every time I think I'm done, they bring up another case, another victim, and I'm dragged back into the nightmare. How am I supposed to deal with this? Every time my phone rings, I wonder if it's going to be another shooting, another death, another family torn apart. And when I finally get home, exhausted and broken, it's still ringing, waiting for me to pick up, ready to drop another bombshell. It's getting harder to cope, harder to keep going. The man's voice wavers, a hint of accusation in his tone. You feel your throat tighten, heart pounding as you realize this could be another parental confrontation like the last one that left you awake all night.

Triggering Event: The man, a software engineer with silver hair and hunched shoulders from years of hunching over screens, woke up to an email from his son's school. The subject line read: "Urgent - Absence Report." He felt a pang in his chest as he worried about what this could mean for his only child, now so far away.
Generated Assessment: You know, I just got an email from my son saying he won't be able to make it to his math test today. What the fuck? He's been having some issues lately, but I didn't think it was bad enough to miss class. Now he's telling me he can't even get out of bed? I'm fucking pissed off! How is he supposed to catch up if he misses every single day? It doesn't make sense at all. But noooo, I have to worry about this shit. Shouldn't he be able to handle something like this on his own? Shouldn't he be more responsible? I've worked hard to teach him how to take care of himself. And now, because he's too fucking lazy to study, he's going to ruin his whole academic year because he can't even follow simple instructions? This is just another example of how fucked up everything has become. My kid doesn't even need to be sick; he needs to show up to school just to prove he's still alive. That's just the world we live in now. People expect you to keep up with them no matter what. If you're not perfect, you're behind. I swear, kids these days have it easy compared to us. Triggering Event: A young officer, barely out of her academy training, laughed loudly at something unseen in her phone. She looked up, catching the retired officer's eye. "Just a meme," she said, grinning. The older woman nodded, but her eyes lingered on the younger one's wedding ring. It was shiny and new, a stark contrast to hers, worn thin by time. A twinge of jealousy stirred in her chest as she watched them leave together, their laughter echoing down the hall.
Generated Assessment: Oh, I bet that officer is *just* laughing about how funny memes are. I mean, who wouldn't? I'm pretty sure most people would find humor in things they see on their phones, right? And what's with this whole "new" thing? Just because it's a fresh ring doesn't mean it's always going to be... well, new. Maybe she'll lose it, or someone will break it, or she'll just get bored with it. Or maybe—oh wait, no, she won't. Because, you know, everyone loves rings. They're so universal. And I'm sure she'll keep wearing it for years and years. After all, who ever loses their favorite ring? Never happens. But, hey, if it does happen, we can always blame it on the retiree who wore theirs too long. It's probably not weird that the retired officer feels jealous. I mean, why wouldn't she? That young officer looks so happy, while she's probably thinking about how much happier she could've been if she'd made different choices. Or maybe she's just tired of being overworked. Yeah, that's it. Tired. Not bitter or resentful at all. No way she's wondering what could've been if she'd chosen differently. Nope, definitely not that. At least, not now. When she gets back home. Triggering Event: A parent storms into his classroom during lunch, complaining about his lesson plan for their child's "stupid" homework assignment.
Generated Assessment: **Parent**: I'm so disappointed! My son is not doing well. He needs to improve his math skills. This assignment is stupid! **Teacher**: Oh, okay. Well, let me see what we can do. Can you tell me more about what he struggled with? **Parent**: Of course. His teacher said he didn't understand fractions, but he has shown improvement recently. He just doesn't seem to grasp it yet. **Teacher**: Okay, I'll look at that. Let me check the notes from yesterday... (pauses) Yes, here's an example problem he was struggling with. Maybe this will help him understand better. Do you have any suggestions for how he could approach it differently?

Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, alone in his patrol car during an unusually stormy night, receives a frantic call over the radio about a prowler seen near an isolated house. As he pulls up to the property, the power flickers and goes out, plunging him into darkness. His heart races as he checks his weapon, feeling a familiar, unsettling fear from years past.
Generated Assessment: It's so odd how this one situation always brings it all back. The sudden loss of power, the darkness, the fear—each time it feels like a trigger. It's been years since I've had to go through this, but I can still feel it. Like there’s something about the way things are set up here that just makes me feel...off. Even though I know intellectually that nothing is really going on, my mind starts racing with scenarios. And then there’s the guy who called in the report—the desperation in his voice was unmistakable. I could tell he was genuinely scared, but at the same time, I couldn’t help but think he might be trying to cover something up. Maybe he didn’t want anyone else knowing what happened? Or maybe he was just scared for himself? Either way, it’s hard not to wonder if there’s more to the story than he let on. ## Step 1: Identify the Trigger I remember every detail of that night, from the sound of the trees creaking in the wind to the smell of ozone in the air. It’s amazing how much can come back with even the slightest stimulus. You’d think that after everything that’s happened, I’d be able to block some of those memories, but they’re still there, waiting to strike. ## Step 2: Reflect on Past Experiences Looking back, I realize that I’ve always been the type to jump to conclusions. Triggering Event: After a long day at the hospital, he walks into their shared apartment to find his partner laughing with a colleague from work. They're sitting close, glasses of wine untouched, engrossed in conversation about a recent conference they'd both attended. He hadn't been invited.
Generated Assessment: He noticed that she was smiling more than usual and her laughter seemed louder. It looked like she was having fun talking to this guy, who also had a big smile on his face. Their body language was open and relaxed around each other. The atmosphere felt casual, but there were no signs of tension or discomfort. His mind began racing, thinking about how she might be spending time with someone else when she usually spent it with him. He wondered if she thought he was boring compared to him and if she found him less interesting than others. His thoughts kept coming back to whether he could compete with this new colleague for her attention, especially since she didn't seem to notice him right now. He felt left out and ignored, as if he was invisible. The situation made him feel insecure and threatened, and he couldn't shake off the feeling that she might prefer this coworker over him. She wasn't saying anything directly, but the way they were interacting made him feel like an outsider. In his head, everything pointed towards him being replaced. He tried to push these thoughts aside, telling himself he was just being paranoid, but he couldn’t help noticing every little detail that made him think she was spending quality time with this stranger instead of him. Every glance, every laugh, even the way she leaned forward slightly to hear better - all these things fueled his insecurities. Triggering Event: In the early hours of her shift, she noticed the patrol car's radio crackling to life with an urgent call from dispatch. Her heart began to pound as she recognized the address: it was mere blocks away from her home. The report was vague, but the tone was unmistakably grave. She gripped the steering wheel tightly, knuckles turning white, as she sped towards the scene, sirens blaring. With each second ticking by, the panic rose within her, threatening to consume her entirely.
Generated Assessment: She thought to herself, "Why can't I be like that one officer? He's always so calm, even during the most critical calls." As she approached the scene, the tension mounted, and her mind flashed back to times when she'd felt inadequate compared to colleagues. Why did she have to be the one to get stuck with the toughest shifts? This wasn't the first time she'd found herself comparing herself unfavorably to someone else. There were instances where she'd felt overshadowed by coworkers, wondering why she couldn't measure up. It seemed every time she looked around, there was someone else handling things with ease, making her feel like she was lagging behind. In moments like these, she couldn't help but think about how she could improve. She'd try to push aside the doubts, focusing instead on what she knew she could control. But deep down, the voice lingered, echoing her feelings of inadequacy. As she stepped out of the patrol car, the sound of sirens grew louder, and the urgency of the situation hit her like a punch to the gut. For a moment, everything seemed to slow down, and all she could think about was the weight of responsibility bearing down on her shoulders. But then, something shifted inside her. She took a deep breath, letting go of some of that tension. It was just another day, after all. And though the job was demanding, she had skills and training that made her uniquely qualified for this role.

Triggering Event: He noticed the same car parked outside his apartment building for three nights straight, even when it shouldn't be there. He didn't recognize the make or model, but he could swear it was always in the same spot, its dark windows reflecting the harsh streetlights like empty eye sockets. He started taking different routes home from work, his heart pounding as he darted glances over his shoulder, convinced someone was watching him.

He felt trapped, like he was being watched by unseen forces, and he couldn’t shake the feeling that this was just the beginning. Every glance at the car made him feel like he was staring into the abyss, and he couldn’t help but wonder if anyone else knew about it. The thought sent shivers down his spine, making him quicken his pace. As he walked back to his apartment, he felt like he was being herded toward some unknown fate. Triggering Event: He entered the crime scene, the stench of decay already heavy in the air. It was an alleyway behind a row of old factories, where the rats were king and the rain hadn't washed away the filth for months. The body lay face down in a puddle of rainwater, bloated and discolored. A rat scurried across its back, pausing to gnaw on a piece of flesh before disappearing into the shadows. He felt his stomach lurch, but he'd seen worse, hadn't he? Yet today, it was different. Today, it felt like his uniform was tainted, like the disgust he felt wasn't just for the crime, but for himself. For being a part of this world that could create such scenes.
Generated Assessment: It's disgusting how he got killed by those rats. It's a shame. They're innocent animals. But they're vicious. You can't trust them. Not when you see what they're capable of. And yet, I'm so fucking disgusted by him, even after all these years. Even now, when I think about it, I still feel sick to my stomach. He shouldn't have been there, shouldn't have been a victim of those rats. That's why I keep thinking about this case, always remembering how it made me feel. I never thought I'd get over it, but here I am, still nauseous whenever I think about it. Maybe if he had stayed away from that place, none of this would have happened. We should've known better than to go there. Or maybe we did know, but we chose to ignore it anyway. Why else would we keep coming back? We shouldn't have been so stupid. If we'd just left well enough alone, none of this would've happened. Instead, we kept going, right into the heart of danger. Now, every time I see a rat, I remember how he died. How he was torn apart by those very creatures. Those monsters shouldn't exist. They shouldn't be allowed anywhere near us. Yet here I am, still haunted by memories of that day. There's no excuse for what those rats did. No one deserves to die like that. Especially not someone who didn't deserve it.
